chiefComplaint: Newborn exhibiting excessive irritability, high-pitched cry, tremors, and poor feeding within the first 24 hours of life following maternal opioid use during pregnancy.
presentIllness:
38 week 4 day neonate, was delivered via vaginal birth to a 23 year-old G1P1 mother with a history of opioid use disorder on medication-assisted treatment (MAT) with [methadone/buprenorphine] throughout pregnancy. Maternal prenatal labs were negative and there were no reported complications during pregnancy or delivery.
The infant was admitted to NICU for observation due to in-utero opioid exposure. At approximately 4 hours post-admission, the infant exhibited signs of withdrawal, including high-pitched cry, tremors, loose stools, yawning, and poor feeding. A Finnegan Neonatal Abstinence Score was obtained, with a score of 12, indicating moderate withdrawal symptoms. No seizures or respiratory distress were noted. The infant is currently on room air with stable vital signs. Feeding attempts have been suboptimal, requiring frequent pacing and support.
reasonForVisit: Evaluation and management of suspected neonatal withdrawal symptoms in a newborn with in-utero opioid exposure (maternal opioid use disorder on MAT).
pastMedicalHistory:
Maternal History:
Opioid Use Disorder, on medication-assisted treatment (MAT) with [methadone/buprenorphine] throughout pregnancy.
Prenatal care established at 16 weeks
No reported use of illicit substances after initiation of MAT.
Negative for HIV, hepatitis B/C, and syphilis.
Group B Streptococcus: negative.
No gestational diabetes or hypertension reported.

Pregnancy and Delivery:
Full-term infant delivered via vaginal without complications.
Apgar scores: [4 at 1 min,6X at 5 min].
Birth weight: [3000 g], appropriate for gestational age.

Neonatal Presentation:
Admitted for observation due to in-utero opioid exposure.
At 4 hours post-admission, Finnegan NAS score: 12 (high-pitched cry, tremors, loose stools, yawning, poor feeding).
No seizures or respiratory distress noted.
reviewOfSystems:
General: Increased irritability, difficulty consoling, frequent yawning.
Neurologic: Tremors (both at rest and with stimulation), hypertonia, exaggerated Moro reflex, no seizures reported.
Gastrointestinal: Loose stools, poor feeding, frequent regurgitation.
Respiratory: Occasional nasal flaring and sneezing; no significant respiratory distress or cyanosis.
Cardiovascular: No reported murmurs or abnormal heart rate; vital signs stable.
Skin: Mild excoriations noted on knees and face from excessive movement; no jaundice or rash.
Sleep: Difficulty maintaining sleep for more than short intervals.
symptoms: high-pitched cry, tremors, loose stools, yawning, poor feeding
labTest1Name: Fentanyl [Presence] in Cord tissue by Confirmatory method
administeringProviderOrgName: SSM Health St. Joseph Hospital - St. Charles
plannedMed1Instructions: 0.05 mg/kg every 3 hours and increase the dose as needed based on response, measured by the modified Finnegan score
vaccine1Name: Hepatitis B vaccine, pediatric or pediatric/adolescent dosage
currentProc1Name: Psychiatric Diagnostic Evaluation with Medical Services
triggerProc1Name: Initial hospital care, per day for the E&M of the neonates 28 days of age or younger, who requires intensive observation, frequent interventions, and other intensive services.
plannedProc1Name: Drug test(s), presumptive, any number of drug classes, qualitative; any number of devices or procedures, (eg, immunoassay) capable of being read by direct optical observation only (eg, dipstick, cups, cards, cartridges) includes sample validation when performed, per date of service
outbreakDetails: No current outbreak or emergency situation related to this case
